bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 13, 1900

div1.p: Lazear reports that United States Army troops have been withdrawn from Guanajay and Pinar del Rio, although the United States will remain in Cuba for several years until a stable government is established. Lazear hopes to have work in Washington after the Cuban research is finished.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 13, 1900
div1.p:
Your letter
of Aug 4 and the
Bookman with Houston's
picture came all night.
The picture is the
prettiest thing I ever
saw. I am having it
toned so that it will
not fade.

Since I wrote last I
made another trip to
Guanajoy returning
with a troop of cavalry
which was a new
experience but rather
a dusty one. The
troops have been with-
drawn from Guanajoy
and Pinar del Rio.
Many other posts will
soon be abandoned.
The complete - evacuation
of Cuba cannot occur
for some times - several
years, a constitution has
to be adopted by
the people and approved by
the United States and a
president its has to
be elected which will
take a good deal of time.

I had à swim yesterday at
a beach near here. It was very
good and I wonder I did not
buy it before.

I too wish I had some work
at home but there does not
seem to be much prospect of it
at present. Army life, on peace
or war has many drawbacks.
The man here are all anxious for
service in China. The prospects now
are that I shall have a year in
Washington after we finish here.
but everything is uncertain.
